readingPart.reading:
basophilhematopoietic stem cellneutrophil
eosinophillymphocyteplatelet
erythrocytemonocyte

questionContent.questionText:
1. mononuclear white blood cell formed in lymph tissue; it is a phagocyte and the precursor of a macrophage [monocyte]

2. thrombocyte or cell fragment that helps blood clot [platelet]

3. cell in the bone marrow that gives rise to different types of blood cells [hematopoietic stem cell]

4. mononuclear leukocyte formed in lymph tissue; produces antibodies [lymphocyte]

5. leukocyte with dense, reddish granules having an affinity for red acidic dye; associated with allergic reactions [eosinophil]

6. red blood cell [erythrocyte]

7. leukocyte (polymorphonuclear granulocyte) formed in the bone marrow; granules do not stain intensely and have a pale color [neutrophil]

8. leukocyte (granulocyte) with dark-staining blue granules; releases histamine and heparin [basophil]

readingPart.reading: blood clotting
white blood cell with numerous, cytoplasmic granules (neutrophil, basophil, and eosinophil)
pertaining to a leukocyte with a single round nucleus; monocytes and lymphocytes are mononuclear leukocytes
pertaining to a white blood cell with a multilobed nucleus; neutrophil
plasma protein; alpha, beta, and gamma (immune) globulins are examples
immature red blood cell
large platelet precursor (forerunner) cell found in bone marrow
monocyte that migrates from blood to tissue spaces; phagocyte that engulfs foreign material and ingests red blood cells
blood protein containing iron; carries oxygen in erythrocytes
liquid portion of blood
immature bone marrow cell that gives rise to granulocytes

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
albumincolony-stimulating factorglobulin
antibodydifferentiationheparin
antigenerythropoietinplasma
bilirubinfibrinogenserum

questionContent.questionText:
1. liquid portion of blood [plasma]

2. orange-yellow pigment produced from hemoglobin when red blood cells are destroyed [bilirubin]

3. plasma protein converted to fibrin in clotting process [fibrinogen]

4. proteins in plasma; separated into alpha, beta, and gamma types [globulin]

5. hormone secreted by the kidneys to stimulate bone marrow to produce red blood cells [erythropoietin]

6. substance (usually foreign) that stimulates production of an antibody [antigen]

7. protein in blood that maintains the proper amount of water in the blood [albumin]

8. specific protein produced by lymphocytes in response to antigens in the blood [antibody]

9. anticoagulant found in blood and tissue cells [heparin]

10. plasma minus clotting proteins and cells [serum]

11. change in structure and function of a cell as it matures [differentiation]

12. protein that stimulates growth of developing blood cells [colony-stimulating factor]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms with the descriptions/definitions that follow.

readingPart.reading: albumin, globulins, fibrinogen, and prothrombin
an antigen normally found on red blood cells of Rh + individuals
destruction or breakdown of red blood cells

prompt.text: A person with type A blood has ________ antigens and ________ antibodies in his or her blood.

readingPart.reading: A; anti-B

prompt.text: A person with type B blood has ________ antigens and ________ antibodies in his or her blood.

readingPart.reading: B; anti-A

prompt.text: A person with type O blood has ________ antigens and ________ antibodies in his or her blood.

readingPart.reading: no A or B; anti-A and anti-B

prompt.text: A person with type AB blood has ________ antigens and _______ antibodies in his or her blood.

readingPart.reading: A and B; no anti-A and no anti-B

prompt.text: Can you transfuse blood from a type A donor into a type B recipient? Why or why not?

readingPart.reading: no; A antigens will react with the anti-A antibodies in the type B recipient's bloodstream

prompt.text: Can you transfuse blood from a type AB donor into a type O recipient? Why or why not?

readingPart.reading: no; A and B antigens will react with the anti-A and anti-B antibodies in the type O recipient's bloodstream
method of separating serum proteins by electrical charge and size
protein with antibody activity; IgG, IgH, IgE
change in structure and function of a cell as it matures; specialization
removal by centrifuge of plasma from withdrawn blood

prompt.text: Why is a person with type O blood the universal donor?

readingPart.reading: type O blood does not contain A or B antigens and therefore will not react with antibodies in any recipient's blood

coagulationheparinthrombin
fibrinprothrombinwarfarin (Coumadin)
fibrinogenserum

questionContent.questionText:
1. anticoagulant substance found in liver cells, blood, and tissues [heparin]

2. protein thread that forms the basis of a blood clot [fibrin]

3. plasma protein that is converted to thrombin in the clotting process [prothrombin]

4. plasma minus clotting proteins and cells [serum]

5. drug given to patients to prevent formation of clots [warfarin (Coumadin)]

6. plasma protein that is converted to fibrin in the clotting process [fibrinogen]

7. process of clotting [coagulation]

8. enzyme that helps convert fibrinogen to fibrin [thrombin]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms related to clotting with the descriptions/definitions that follow.

readingPart.reading: anti/coagul/ant—a substance that prevents clotting
hemoglobin/o/pathy—disease (abnormality) of hemoglobin
cyt/o/logy—study of cells
leuk/o/penia—deficiency of white (blood) cells
morph/o/logy—study of the shape or form (of cells)
mega/kary/o/cyte—cell with a large (mega-) nucleus (kary); platelet precursor
sider/o/penia—deficiency of iron
phag/o/cyte—cell that eats or swallows other cells
myel/o/poiesis—formation of bone marrow
platelet/pheresis—separation of platelets from the rest of the blood
mon/o/blast—immature monocyte
myel/o/dys/plasia—abnormal (ineffective) production of myeloid cells in bone marrow. Myeloid progenitor cells give rise to erythrocytes, granulocytes, and platelets
hem/o/stasis—controlling or stopping the flow of blood
thromb/o/lytic (therapy)— pertaining to treatment using drugs to destroy clots
hemat/o/poiesis—formation of blood cells

instructions.instructions: Divide the following terms into component parts and give the meanings of the complete terms.

readingPart.reading:
coagulopathyleukapheresisthrombocytopenia
eosinophiliamyeloidthrombosis
hematocritneutropenia

questionContent.questionText:
1. derived in bone marrow [myeloid]

2. deficiency of a type of white blood cell [neutropenia]

3. percentage of red blood cells in a volume of blood [hematocrit]

4. increase in a type of white blood cell (seen in allergies) [eosinophilia]

5. abnormal condition of clot formation [thrombosis]

6. separation of white blood cells from a blood sample [leukapheresis]

7. disease of clotting process [coagulopathy]

8. deficiency of platelets [thrombocytopenia]

instructions.instructions: Match the hematology terms with their meanings.

readingPart.reading:
anemiahemoglobinmicrocytosis
anisocytosishemolysispoikilocytosis
erythropoiesishypochromicpolycythemia vera
hematocritmacrocytosisspherocytosis

questionContent.questionText:
1. any irregularity in the shape of red blood cells [poikilocytosis]

2. oxygen-containing protein in red blood cells [hemoglobin]

3. formation of red blood cells [erythropoiesis]

4. deficiency in numbers of red blood cells [anemia]

5. destruction of red blood cells [hemolysis]

6. pertaining to reduction of hemoglobin in red blood cells [hypochromic]

7. variation in size of red blood cells [anisocytosis]

8. abnormal numbers of round, rather than normally biconcave-shaped, red blood cells [spherocytosis]

9. increase in number of small red blood cells [microcytosis]

10. general increase in numbers of red blood cells; erythremia [polycythemia vera]

11. increase in numbers of large red blood cells [macrocytosis]

12. separation of blood so that the percentage of red blood cells in relation to the volume of a blood sample is measured [hematocrit]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms concerning red blood cells with the descriptions/definitions that follow.

readingPart.reading: lack of iron leading to insufficient hemoglobin production
lack of mature erythrocytes caused by inability to absorb vitamin B12 into the bloodstream (intrinsic factor is missing in gastric juice, so B12 is not absorbed)
hereditary disorder of abnormal hemoglobin producing sickleshaped erythrocytes and hemolysis
failure of blood cell production in bone marrow
inherited disorder of abnormal hemoglobin production leading to hypochromia

instructions.instructions: Describe the problem in each of the following forms of anemia.

readingPart.reading: multiple pinpoint hemorrhages and accumulation of blood under the skin (cause may be deficiency of platelets)
abnormal increase in granulocytes in the blood (eosinophilia and basophilia)
excessive bleeding caused by hereditary lack of blood clotting factors
excessive iron deposits throughout the body
malignant neoplasm of bone marrow
infectious disease marked by increased numbers of mononuclear leukocytes and enlarged cervical lymph nodes

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms for blood dyscrasias.

questionContent.questionText:
1. relapse [Symptoms of the disease return]

2. remission [Symptoms of the disease disappear]

3. palliative [Relieving but not curing]

4. Bence Jones protein [Immunoglobulin fragment found in the urine of patients with multiple myeloma]

5. ecchymoses [Large blue or purplish patches on skin (bruises)]

6. pancytopenia [Deficiency of all blood cells]

7. apheresis [Separation of blood into its parts]

8. eosinophilia [Increase in numbers of granulocytes; seen in allergic conditions]

9. petechiae [Tiny purple or flat red spots on skin occurring as a result of small hemorrh]

10. packed cells [Preparation of erythrocytes separated from plasma]

instructions.instructions: Match the term with the meaning from the dropdown.

readingPart.reading:
antiglobulin (Coombs) testhematocritred blood cell count
autologous transfusionhematopoietic stem cell transplantationred blood cell morphology
bone marrow biopsyplatelet countwhite blood cell differential
erythrocyte sedimentation rate

questionContent.questionText:
1. microscopic examination of a stained blood smear to determine the shape of individual red blood cells [red blood cell morphology]

2. percentage of red blood cells in a volume of blood [hematocrit]

3. determines the number of clotting cells per mm3 or μL of blood [platelet count]

4. speed at which erythrocytes settle out of plasma [erythrocyte sedimentation rate]

5. percentages of different types of leukocytes in the blood [white blood cell differential]

6. test for the presence of antibodies that coat and damage erythrocytes [antiglobulin (Coombs) test]

7. peripheral stem cells from a compatible donor are infused into a recipient's vein to repopulate the bone marrow [hematopoietic stem cell transplantation]

8. microscopic examination of a core of bone marrow removed with a needle [bone marrow biopsy]

9. number of erythrocytes per mm3 or μL of blood [red blood cell count]

10. blood is collected from and later reinfused into the same patient [autologous transfusion]

instructions.instructions: Match the laboratory test or clinical procedure with its description.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Gary, a 1-year-old African American child, was failing to gain weight normally. He seemed pale and without energy. His blood tests showed a decreased hemoglobin (5.0 g/dL) and decreased hematocrit (16.5%). After a blood smear revealed abnormally shaped red cells, the physician told Gary's parents that their son had [sickle cell anemia/iron deficiency anemia/hemophilia].

2. While in the hospital, Mr. Klein was told he had an elevated [white blood cell/red blood cell/platelet] count with a "shift to the left." This was information that confirmed his diagnosis of a systemic infection.

3. While Mr. Chen was taking warfarin (Coumadin), a blood thinner, his physician made sure to check his [prothrombin time/hematocrit/sed rate].

4. Sixty-one-year-old Barbara's laboratory tests showed abnormal proteins in her plasma and Bence Jones protein in her urine. She had osteopenia and a fracture in one of her ribs. Her oncologist diagnosed her condition as [multiple myeloma/mononucleosis/thrombocytopenic purpura] . He prescribed analgesics and drugs such as thalidomide and bortezomib (Velcade).

5. Bobby was diagnosed at a very early age with a bleeding disorder called [hemophilia/thalassemia/eosinophili] . He needed factor VIII regularly, especially after even the slightest traumatic injury.

6. Juan was a 9-year-old boy who suddenly noticed many black and blue marks all over his legs. He had a fever and was tired all the time. The physician did a blood test that revealed pancytopenia. A bone marrow biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of [aplastic anemia/acute lymphoid leukemia/polycythemia vera].

7. Alice and her friends had been staying up late for weeks, cramming for exams. She developed a sore throat and swollen lymph nodes in her neck and felt fatigued all the time. Dr. Smith did a blood test, and the results showed lymphocytosis and antibodies to EBV in the bloodstream. His diagnosis was [mononucleosis/leukapheresis/lymphocytopenia].

8. Susan was experiencing heavy menstrual periods [menorrhagia/menorrhea/hemoptysis]. Because of the bleeding, she frequently felt tired and weak and probably was sideropenic. Her physician performed blood tests that revealed her problem as [ iron deficiency anemia/thrombocytopenia/pernicious anemia].

9. Dr. Harris examined a highly allergic patient and sent a blood sample to a specialist, a [hematologic/pulmonary/cardiovascular]pathologist. The specialist stained the blood smear and found an abundance of leukocytes with dense, reddish granules. She made the diagnosis of [eosinophilia/basophilia/neutrophilia].

10. George’s blood cell counts had been falling in recent weeks. His scheduled laparotomy was canceled because blood tests revealed [pancytopenia/plasmapheresis/myelopoiesis]. Bone marrow biopsy determined that the cause was [hypoplasia/hyperplasia/differentiation] of all cellular elements.

instructions.instructions: Select the terms that best complete the meaning of the sentences.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Hgb [hemoglobin]
2. GVHD [graft-versus-host disease]
3. ALL [acute lymphoid leukemia]
4. PT [prothrombin time]
5. CML [chronic myeloid leukemia/chronic myelocytic leukemia]
6. EPO [erythropoietin]
7. IgA, IgE, IgD [immunoglobulins]
8. CLL [chronic lymphoid leukemia]
9. Hct [hematocrit]
10. AML [acute myeloid leukemia/acute myelocytic leukemia]

1. Blood protein that transports oxygen to tissues. 
[hemoglobin]
2. Immune reaction of donor's cells/tissue to recipient's cells/tissue; a possible outcome of hematopoietic stem cell or bone marrow transplantation. 
[graft-versus-host disease]
3. Malignant condition of white blood cells; immature lymphocytes predominate. 
[acute lymphoid leukemia]
4. Test used to follow patients who are taking certain anticoagulants.
[prothrombin time]
5. Malignant condition of white blood cells in which both mature and immature granulocytes are present; a slowly progressive illness.
[chronic myeloid (myelocytic) leukemia]
6. Hormone that stimulates the growth of red blood cells.
[erythropoietin]
7. Proteins containing antibodies.
[immunoglobulins]
8. Malignant condition of white blood cells in which relatively mature lymphocytes predominate in lymph nodes, spleen, and bone marrow; usually seen in elderly patients.
[chronic lymphoid leukemia]
9. Percentage of red cells in blood volume.
[hematocrit]
10. Malignant condition of white blood cells; immature granulocytes (myeloblasts) predominate.
[acute myeloid (myelocytic) leukemia]

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the term that best matches the description.
